pros: The best thing about being a designer for THD is they will take a lump of cc lay and train it to be Bob Villa... Well, more like Tim the Toolman. They have the most comprehensive training in the industry, but they pay for it with lower salaries than our competitors. The turnover is high, workload is heavy and they micromanage the hell out of you. There's mandatory training from HR, safety training, monthly training from vendors, customer follow up, lead generation... Oh! And can you please cover appliances and flooring while designing a $30,000 kitchen without making a mistake and ask them to open a credit card, sell the install and make it a "perfect kitchen"?. It's a lot. If you live what you do, the PowerPoints and reports won't bother you. But if you live what you do, it will crush you when some crook plays the system, complains for nothing and gets a refund on that perfect kitchen. It is not for the faint of heart or thin skinned person
cons: See above....I ramble a lot...

job_title: Sales Associate/Cashier in Clifton Park, NY
pros: Loved the job, my co workers and customers.
cons: Management lacking! Imagine working so hard to try to advance in the company and people who knew less and had been with the company for much less time gets the job instead, mind you after the other employee gets promoted they’re constantly asking you how to do their job. Also HR is completely lacking! When I had finally found another job to replace this one with, respectfully gave a two week notice, about a week into working my last two weeks I was in the middle of a shift and was told I could go home and that my shifts for the following week I was not needed, we were actually in desperate need of more employees and on top of that I never received my last two checks at all even though I was set up for direct deposit, contacted HR daily had to leave a voicemail every time for about a week straight before I got a call back to discuss the matter, to then be told I didn’t get a check my last two weeks because “it was all taken out due taxes” not sure how that happens when it’s taken out by a percentage of the overall check and I do not owe any money to the IRS, I asked for further information about this and they could not/would not elaborate on that, nor was I pointed in the direction of somebody who could. Overall just completely disappointed!

job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Austin, TX
pros:
There is a strong company culture that covers a range of values, but it can be summarized as "doing the right thing" And valuing the customers and front line staff, with everyone in corporate being subservient the front line. We have many thing to be proud of with regard to how we support the community and operate as a company. A further feature that makes this attractive as an employer is they do well when things are falling apart... And when times are good, they do well. Whether we are selling tarps and 2x4's for hurricane recovery, or are selling plants and home improvements. The things that drive people to do things drive them to Home Depot to buy supplies. 

Also, since the IT teams OPTIONALLY work from home (except people in the datacenters and other things that require hands on) you can be an in-the-office person or a work from home. We are very good at communication, and I have face to face meetings with my co-workers all day long, without ever leaving my home, or having to put shoes on. Many new hires are alowed to live wherever they want, so you can take that job in atlanta, while living in your beachfront home wherever makes you happy (as long as it is in the us, and your state isn't a legal problem (looks at California).
It makes a difference if you have a good manager, most managers are very good.
People that work at Home Depot tend to stay at home depot, or quit and come back to negotiate a higher salary.
401k is good, insurance has lots of options and is better than most, there are discount stock buying plans where you can buy stock 15% below the going rate. Then there are stock awards where they give you huge chunks of stock each year, along with modest bonuses.

There is a massive emphasis on career development, so when your manager asks you what you picture yourself doing in 5 years, the next sentence is "Let's build a plan with action items to achieve that goal". MANY people in the top layers of the company started sweeping the floors... And Many people in the stores are retired trades people from the building trades finding a comfortable place to work until they are 100 in a comfortable air conditioned indoor space where they can share their 60 years experience with customers free from the hazards they used to face in their trade. It is a place to start a career, and a place to end your career. We value seniors (like myself) as well as the youthful team members.
cons: It is a company with a half million employees, so there is the baggage that comes with that. If you get a bad manager that can be unfortunate, but there aren't many of those.

Management implements policies that directly impede our ability to do our job. No extra compensation for any lift licenses. Limited avenues to get shifts off or covered. Expectations from management to help out in other departments, while disregarding the tasks that need to be done in our own. Management would rather have departments be understaffed and neglected, than hire more workers for coverage. No upward trajectory unless you are in a full time position. Merit based evaluations have been postponed until 2023 because of store wide flat pay increases.

pros: Hours are flexible, you get decent hours in the beginning or during peak times. Big and decent break room, overall an okay environment
cons: Management sucked. A manager in particular was gone on leave then came back and made working there miserable. They were very much into drama even though they wanted us to “report drama and work drama free”. Head cashiers think they are better than you most of the time and they sometimes are kind about how they explain things. The environment was okay, customers were sometimes nicer than the actual employees. If you’re thrown outside once to garden expect to be there ALWAYS. They are not the greatest at being on time with your breaks or your lunches especially if you’re out at garden, you are basically forgotten about even in the heat and cold weather. Being pushed to push credit cards was always a drag especially during the peak of a pandemic. Even if you give great customer service and do your absolute best to ask for credit cards and a customer says no, it was still somehow your fault. Didn’t matter if the customer had one already or respectfully did not want one, you had to have a least six credit cards PER day if not you were in trouble basically. They grade your performance essentially by the amount of credit cards and if you don’t do well at getting those especially if you’re out at garden (way harder to get them out there if you’re always out there since people just buy small plants) you probably won’t get scheduled as much

job_title: Cashier/Customer Service Desk in Atlanta, GA
pros: Coworkers were fun, helpful and nice to work with usually. Occasional fun customer who would be fun to get along with. Once you’re done w your job you go home and not have to think about work.
cons: Occasional attitude from managers who would become irritable with you sometimes when you inevitably frequently needed cash requests. Very low pay ESPECIALLY for the many rude people you would have to encounter. Was only doable at the time bc of the covid bonus. It was stressful working with rude customers who would sometimes curse you out, which some refused to wear their masks at a time when so little was known about covid. Also stressful and unreasonable system for answering the phone when dealing with long lines. Customers would be highly irritated but there was nothing that could be done when having to choose between answering the always ringing phone and the ever building up line. A lot of methods learned were self taught and even the people who were there longer than you would step in to try to help but when they didn’t know what to do either, it was extra stressful when one couldn’t reach a manager to assist you while customers are there looking at you like you don’t know what you’re doing.

pros: There are a handful of nice people at the Southlake Texas store, but that’s the only good thing.
cons:
Highly (very bad) toxic work environment with micromanaging “supervisors” and management who are not on the same page. The high rate of turnover at this location is due to the fact bad management keeps doing the same thing- treating associates poorly. The employees that do stay have a way of ignoring the disrespectful and degrading behavior, but most don’t put up with it.

A few contractors who spend a great deal of money there just started doing business with #Lowes because of the management and the dislike of how Home Depot treats their business. One contractor witnessed a manager berating a forklift driver. After this, the company owner said this location makes him sick to his stomach and switching to Lowes in Southlake Texas.

“You can go” is the attitude at this location and I regret working there. Very dirty and disorganized to the extreme. It was a nightmare.

job_title: Sales Floor Associate in Panama City, FL
pros:
1. Company Policies 
2. Stays Current to world events
cons:
1. Stores can be different based on Store Managers approach to the business. I have witnessed people that are family or friends to ASM/SM get picked over qualified candidates for Department head positions.
2. No sense of management to work schedules, the "system" creates a work schedule four weeks out based on hours store is given. Unfortunately Management does not pay any attention to these schedules. Will remove the one person working in a department to help in another department that did not schedule anyone and then management will leave your department empty while your filled in another.
3. The pay scale is terrible cashiers get paid more than those starting on floor, while new hires are making more money than some that have been with company for five years or more.
4. Unfortunately most companies are going to be based on your experience with management and not with the actual company policies.
5. The Late to work policy counts as a occurrence on your work record, making it so that if you are going to be late its better to just call in and state that you are not coming in as you can at least have an excuse from your occurrence. 
6. Corporate HR does listen to your events of HIPPA, Harassment and unfair conditions. Unfortunately that is how far as it goes in the cases that I have reported.
7. Do not give raises for Forklift and Reach Truck skills
8. Does not keep up with competitors (Lowes) pay or salary range.

pros: Benefits from Company are Great. Pay is Decent if you don't have College Degree. It's great for a retired person who doesn't mind being on their feet four to eight hours a day. And for a High School Kid, it's the best job they can have for the summer to appreciate going to College and getting a degree. Working at Home Depot is hard work. Customer Service is key. If you learn the ropes from an associate who cares about their job, then you'll have fun. If you're an outgoing person and you like your day to be different every single day, this job and any position at the Home Depot is for you. Management is great if you can find a team of managers that supports its associates.
cons: I worked at Home Depot for ten years. When I started working at Depot, every day I felt like I would lose my job. I had some really bad managers. Over ten years, and moving to three stores, my second manager was the worst. He had it out for me. It was horrible. I came home every day and cried. He finally got fired. I realized that most upper management gets fired or leaves, you get to stay, because you are too valuable. Kitchen Designers are the cream of the crop for the company. They make top dollar and make more money for the company than any other department. So, if you don't screw up kitchens and lose money for them, you are never going to lose your job. It's hard to find someone to replace you. However, it's highly stressful. You have sales goals every month, which aren't hard to make. (Because they understaff) You do get cranky in the summertime because the store gets hot, customers are hot, and there isn't enough time to finish anything, so you are always behind the eight ball. Overtime is frowned upon. If you're habitually late, you will get fired. I have seen that happen to many associates. And it's a warehouse, you'll get dirty. Wearing an apron all day gets very old. Sometimes I just wanted to dress up in a nice dress to meet with my kitchen customers and not wear the orange apron. I wanted to look more professional.

review_title: The Home Depot: My Experience As an Employee
job_title: Sales Associate/Cashier in Fort Myers, FL
pros:
Great wage for high school and university students. a competitive $12/hr is always nice. 

Great work environment. You meet all kinds of contractors and DIY homeowners working on projects. You learn a thing or two about the materials they buy.

Decent benefits. Discount stock price, concert tickets, discount electronics/technology, paid vacation and sick time, 401-k matching, retirement, tuition payments, and so much more. 

Great work morale. Stores vary, but my store has a high volume of customers, so there is no time for panicking or overtime. My ASMs, ASDS, and SM are very considerate of work-life balance.
cons:
In regards to work culture, ethic, and environment, stores vary. It's a real shame how a change in store volume can drastically impact how you are treated at your store. I have worked as a cashier at two different stores. I transferred out of the first one because of how inconsiderate they were of my time as a student, my health, and my training. I returned back to the original store I worked at a year prior, and my store managers are 100% more caring, more considerate, not pushy, and more than willing to help. 

Honestly it's a gamble. If you're lucky, you'll have a great team like my current one. If not, you'll have a bad experience. 

I recommend to any prospecting employees to ask store staff about their experiences with management, hours, and recognition. I also recommend negotiating during your interview how you want the store to bring the best out of you as an associate. this could be anything from schedule, wage, and treatment.

review_title: Great co-workers, but poor working conditions because of a lack of enough people
job_title: Retail Sales Associate in Portland, OR
pros: My Co-workers were great, even the managers were kind and I got along well with everyone. I also learned a lot about the tools and department that I was in and really did enjoy some parts of my work. There are also some good benefits for a retail job including things like help with college tuition.
cons: There weren't enough people to meet customer demands and I felt like I had to make the choice between doing things safely and satisfying customers when I was the only one working in my department. They constantly stress safety in public, but I felt like in my day-to-day work I didn't feel like I had the resources to do things the right way. My department head was horribly overworked and ended up getting hurt, and that led to me realizing I needed to get out. They were also extremely slow to initiate proper covid precations. I also feel like the environment didn't really foster a good work ethic. Many of my co-workers seemed burned out, and hard work wasn't really rewarded.

pros: I don’t know about other stores but my store was awful, we were the worst in the district. But management didn’t care what you did, I know people that had over 40 occurrences and they never got written up/fired.
cons: Managers don’t know how to run their stores, no one cleans, no one answers when you try to call out, no separation between work and social life. Cashiering is terrible, head cashier don’t do nothing but sit on their phones, then have the nerve to call for back up cashiers. Also everyone acts like it’s high school. But this is just my old store

I can go on n on about the problems I've encountered in my short experience with THD ....... Simply put ....... unbelievable !!!!!!
